summary:
Our main activities includes research and coaching in human online behavior, digital wellbeing, and digital pollution.

Having sustainable control over our digital behavior and the ways in which we dispose or use our digital ecosystems, implies developing, strengthening, and maintaining a new series of skills at the individual and collective level, based on the understanding of the benefits and consequences of our strategies and online activities.

My professional background includes a mastery certification in business strategies for the Metaverse, sustainable digitalization, digital wellbeing, and digital transformation; Theory of Change; Holistic individual and corporate transformation processes; Investigative journalism.
 
As a coach, I am certified by the International Coach Federation (ICF).

My book "Depredadores Digitales" (2021,Círculo Rojo), is a worldwide investigation where I delve into the complexity of a silent polluting carbon footprint.

El libro es una reflexión crítica al aceleramiento digital provocado por la pandemia y la guerra de Ucrania, ofrece la sobriedad digital como respuesta al exceso de daño que hace la huella de carbono digital.

As an expert in digital carbon footprint and sustainable development policies, I have been advising the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Costa Rica since March 2021 on how to include the issue of digital carbon footprint in the country's sustainable development policies.

I have a deep understanding of the impact that digital carbon footprint can have on the environment, and have used my expertise to advise the Ministry of Foreign Affairs on the most effective ways to address this issue.

Through my work with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, I have developed strategies that enable the country to take a leadership role in addressing the issue of digital carbon footprint. By integrating this issue into the country's sustainable development policies, we can ensure that Costa Rica is doing its part to protect the environment and promote sustainable development.

profile_positions.company: Depredadores Digitales: una historia de la huella de carbono de la industria digital
profile_positions.description:
This book is the result of a worldwide investigation of the digital carbon footprint.
If we consider access to the Internet a universal right, so is knowing the digital carbon footprint we generate. If it were a country, the digital industry would be the fourth most polluted nation on the planet.
According to United Nations "if the projections are true, the internet would be responsible for an additional 1.7 billion tons of GHG emissions per year by 2030, corresponding to Russia’s 2019 CO2 emissions".
In East and West, in the last five years, different independent reports warn that the energy consumption of our digital ecosystem is not sustainable with respect to the supply of energy and materials that it requires.
It is an environmental contamination that, not seeing it, we relativize.
Our digital world creates a carbon footprint that we are barely understanding.

profile_positions.description:
For almost 2 years, I had the privilege of working at the front lines of the battle against Covid19, alongside the GGDru and the local government in the city of Utrecht in the Netherlands. It was a time of unprecedented challenges, but also of remarkable resilience and cooperation.

As a logistical and operational expert, I played a key role in ensuring that vital resources were delivered to those who needed them most. Working closely with the local community, I saw firsthand the incredible dedication and compassion of healthcare workers, first responders, and ordinary citizens. Together, we worked to keep our communities safe and healthy, even in the face of tremendous adversity.

And now, as we begin to emerge from the pandemic, I'm excited to announce a new project that builds on that experience. Drawing on my time working with the GGDru and the local government, I'm embarking on a social research and literary project that will explore the impact of Covid19 on our communities and our world.

Through interviews, research, and personal reflections, I hope to capture the stories of those who lived through this challenging time - the joys, the sorrows, and the lessons learned. My goal is to create a compelling and insightful portrait of this moment in history, one that will inform and inspire readers for years to come.

profile_positions.description:
For years, I've had the privilege of reporting on some of the most pressing issues facing Latin America today. From environmental, economic and political upheaval to social and cultural changes, I've covered it all - and I've done it for some of the most respected media outlets in the region.

My work has taken me across the continent, from Costa Rica to Mexico to Uruguay and beyond. I've reported for La Nación and El Financiero in Costa Rica, Excelsior and Reforma in Mexico, Brecha in Uruguay, La Prensa in Nicaragua, Cambio and Semana in Colombia, Newsweek Spanish, El Universal in Venezuela, and many others.

Through my reporting, I've had the opportunity to meet and interview people from all walks of life, from government officials to activists to ordinary citizens. I've seen the struggles and triumphs of the region firsthand, and I'm committed to sharing those stories with the world.

But my work is more than just reporting the news. I'm passionate about using journalism as a tool for change, and I believe that by shining a light on the issues facing Latin America, we can inspire action and create a better future for all.

Whether I'm reporting on corruption in politics, inequality in society, or the impact of globalization on local communities, I'm always striving to tell the most compelling and accurate stories possible. And I'm always looking for new opportunities to explore and understand this fascinating and complex region.

profile_positions.description:
With extensive experience in managing teams and implementing innovative projects, I have a unique set of skills that can drive positive change in the Latin American region and beyond.

As a manager of the Latin American department, I have a talent for leading teams to achieve their goals. I have implemented the Theory of Change, Non-Violent Communication, and Peace Dialogue in regional projects in Mexico, Venezuela, and Cuba, and have seen the transformative impact these theories can have on individuals and communities.

In addition to team management, I bring project management and strategic thinking skills to the table. I have a talent for advocacy and lobbying in The Netherlands, Latin America, and Europe, and have successfully managed fundraising and budgets for regional projects.

As an institutional representative, I have built strong relationships with national and international stakeholders, and have successfully advocated for positive change at local and global levels. I have a talent for digital marketing and have worked on the development of trans-media, multimedia, and new digital platforms such as elToque.

Through my work in debates, workshops, and forums, I have facilitated meaningful conversations that have led to positive change. I am skilled in storytelling and corporate communication, which enables me to craft compelling narratives that resonate with target audiences.

Overall, I bring a blend of skills to the table, including team management, project management and strategic thinking, advocacy and lobbying, fundraising and budget management, institutional representation, digital marketing and strategies, and storytelling and corporate communication. Whether working in Latin America or beyond, I'm excited to use these skills to drive positive change in the world.
